1.brief: to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)

the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

stability; (figuratively) certainty, truth, trustworthiness
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle

knowledge

2.brief: properly, to adjure, i.e. (usually in a bad sense) imprecate
to be untrue, in word (to lie, feign, disown) or deed (to disappoint, fail, cringe)
properly, to dash in pieces, i.e. kill (a human being), especially to murder
to thieve (literally or figuratively); by implication, to deceive
to commit adultery; figuratively, to apostatize
to break out (in many applications, direct and indirect, literal and figurative)
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)

properly, to touch, i.e. lay the hand upon (for any purpose; euphemistically, to lie with a woman); by implication, to reach (figuratively, to arrive, acquire); violently, to strike (punish, defeat, destroy, etc.)

3.brief: above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to droop; by implication to be sick, to mourn
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
a bird (as covered with feathers, or rather as covering with wings), often collectively
the sky (as aloft; the dual perhaps alluding to the visible arch in which the clouds move, as well as to the higher ether where the celestial bodies revolve)
properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
to gather for any purpose; hence, to receive, take away, i.e. remove (destroy, leave behind, put up, restore, etc.)

4.brief: a particle of affirmation, surely; hence (by limitation) only
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
properly, to toss, i.e. grapple; mostly figuratively, to wrangle, i.e. hold a controversy; (by implication) to defend

to be right (i.e. correct); reciprocal, to argue; causatively, to decide, justify or convict

literally one officiating, a priest; also (by courtesy) an acting priest (although a layman)

to be dumb or silent; hence, to fail or perish; trans. to destroy

near, with or among; often in general, to
